article.headline: Wells Fargo's stock dives after wider-than-expected loss, revenue miss
article.body: Shares of Wells Fargo & Co. WFC, took a 3.7% dive in premarket trading Tuesday, after the bank swung to wider-than-expected second-quarter loss and revenue that fell more than forecast, as the allowance for credit loss reserves increased $8.4 billion. The bank reported a net loss of $2.69 billion, or 66 cents a share, after net income of $5.85 billion, or $1.30 a share, in the year-ago period. The FactSet consensus was for a loss of 16 cents a share. Total revenue dropped 17% to $17.84 billion, with net interest income declining 18% to $9.9 billion to miss the FactSet consensus of $10.3 billion, and noninterest income falling 16% to $8.0 billion to miss expectations of $8.1 billion. Net interest margin fell to 2.25% from 2.82%, below expectations of 2.33%. within noninterest income, market sensitive revenue was $1.6 billion, after a loss of $1.1 billion. The allowance for credit losses for loans totaled $20.4 billion, up $8.4 billion from the end of the first quarter, including a $6.4 billion increase for commercial loans, citing forecasted credit deterioration as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The stock has dropped 15.8% over the past three months through Monday, while the S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% has rallied 10.9%.
